content:
I apologize for any confusion my earlier response may have caused. Upon further investigation, it appears that the specific incident involving Reynald de Chatillon and the Patriarch of Antioch is primarily described in William of Tyre's "A History of Deeds Done Beyond the Sea," rather than in multiple accounts.

While I was incorrect in my earlier response that "some accounts" refer to Reynald's demand for a large ransom, it is true that William of Tyre's account describes Reynald taking the Patriarch of Antioch captive and demanding a large ransom for his release. According to William of Tyre, Reynald stripped the Patriarch naked and smeared him with honey, but he was eventually ransomed at a high price.

Again, I apologize for any confusion my earlier responses may have caused, and I hope this more accurate information is helpful.
